content:
TNX for offer to help. I'm up and running now. I wanted to give feedback. I uninstalled old Thunderbird. Then I looked for it in all the program directories and in the user data areas. What I found I deleted manually. TB uninstall doesn’t uninstall everything.

I downloaded and installed TB 128.5.2 esr . I connected TB to Gmail for email, and GCal for calendar (IMAP), also the Gaddress book/contacts. I don’t use Tasks. This was easy - glad 'cause I wouldn't have known what links to enter. Issues found: Process of verifying "me" confusing, failed once. Didn't have PIN, "Verifying it's you . . . " message just hangs - white screen never completes or complains. "Complete sign-in . . . passkey" - what is a Passkey? Explain. Got a number of error pop-ups when dismissing old events and calendar link downloaded GCal. Quite a lot of setups to set: Calendar doesn't update to 10 hour days/display; no "Save" button on setup screen after changes. "Files & Attachments" missing "ADD type" button. BTW-all this data is in Gmail and should have come across when linked. TNX Ray Turner
creator: rayjturner

content:
rayjturner said
TNX for offer to help. I'm up and running now. I wanted to give feedback. I uninstalled old Thunderbird. Then I looked for it in all the program directories and in the user data areas. What I found I deleted manually. TB uninstall doesn’t uninstall everything.

I is not intended to. So you have identified the uninstall acting as designed.

I downloaded and installed TB 128.5.2 esr . I connected TB to Gmail for email, and GCal for calendar (IMAP), also the Gaddress book/contacts. I don’t use Tasks. This was easy - glad 'cause I wouldn't have known what links to enter. Issues found: Process of verifying "me" confusing, failed once. Didn't have PIN, "Verifying it's you . . . " message just hangs - white screen never completes or complains. "Complete sign-in . . . passkey" - what is a Passkey? Explain.

That entire flow of screens are web paged server by Google to you. It is much like when you click on of those sign in with Google links on the web. Thunderbird has no control over the content or anything else about the oAuth authentication flow. It just gets to save the response from Google to authenticate you going forward. So if you have comments on it to pass on. Please notify google how confusing it is. No one at Thunderbird has any influence at Google about how they undertake their business.

Got a number of error pop-ups when dismissing old events and calendar link downloaded GCal. Quite a lot of setups to set: Calendar doesn't update to 10 hour days/display; no "Save" button on setup screen after changes. "Files & Attachments" missing "ADD type" button. BTW-all this data is in Gmail and should have come across when linked. TNX Ray Turner

I have to guess that the PIN is the one google sent to your mobile phone because you had two factor authentication enabled with Google. But really not knowing what your security set up with Google is I can do little but guess. The same must be said for anyone else in this forum.

As for wanting a Save button. So do I. However the developers removed them as a design feature some years ago. So I guess you like me will have to get used to having things save as soon as the field looses focus.

I would also like to point out that opening an unknown file type leads you through a point and click process to select the correct helper application for that MIME type or as it is new called Media type. The file extension is not considered in this as identifying a files"type". Using the extension is basically exclusively a windows thing even the internet uses media types. This means that using an add button is not really going to be all that useful as not all DAT files are text, and not all DOC files come from the same version of Word.

content: If you're comfortable with Windows File Explorer, you can do this: - on old pc, highlight the folder, rightclick and select properties. That gives exact location on drive - exit thunderbird and copy the file (NOT the msf) to extenal media - on new PC, click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and cick 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - click the Mail folder and then the Local Folders folder' - past the copied folder here in local folders - restart thunderbird

content:
You cannot change IMAP to POP. Instead, you would need to create a POP account. You could keep the IMAP account or remove, as desired. Help is an entry on the hamburger menu in upper right.

Another approach would be to have the importexporttools NG addon on both computers. you could highlight the folder on old PC, select the importexporttools option to export eml messages with index and subfolders. eml and on new pc, highlight Local Folders, rightclick and select the option to import eml messages from directory and subdirectories.

content:
Sorry for the error.

"MT" means what?

You haven't specified what authentication method is set, but it is typically oauth in which case the answer is again going to be https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1477809#answer-1693122. Even though Thunderbird prompts for a password, it only saves the oauth token.
creator: wsmwk

content:
MT = Mozilla Thunderbird

Once again.. I'm not asking for password for Google IMAP account. In my case Google password is only need to connect Google Calandar by plug-in. Google then requires confirmation through its additional window (browser, not through MT checkbox), but is secondary issue.

Main problem is with password from simple mail account from xxx domain. And what does it matter what the authorization method is for this account??? Regardless of whether it would be a regular password or SSL, after entering it correctly (and setting up the account) and confirming the "checkbox" it should be remembered (otherwise the server will check the authorization and reject it, right?). In the meantime I enter it, check my email, close the program, open it and it asks for the password again. Additionally, if the password was remembered it should be in the password manager, but it is not.
creator: rsiuta

content:
It DOES matter what authentication is used.

Part of the whole point of oauth is your password doesn't get saved - a token is stored for your future access, not the password. This will not be changed.

To learn more https://www.techtarget.com/searchapparchitecture/definition/OAuth
creator: wsmwk

content: No, there is no AOuth on my mail server, there is "simple password". This is not a Gmail account.
creator: rsiuta

content:
It DOES matter what authentication is used.

No, you are wrong. If it were, the mail server would reject the connection (or I would not finish configuring the account), but that is not happening. I can receive, send mail, etc.

As proof of this, I have configured the account on another unit with MT ver. 115 (max. for W7) and with the same settings, BINGO - it works.

Additionally, on the same unit where the problem is, I also returned to version 115, creating a new profile - and it also works. So it is clearly a problem with MT itself in version 128.

content:
A quando risale il backup più recente di cui disponi?

Senza backup puoi provare questa procedura, ma non ci sono garanzieche funzioni:

  1. Fare un backup integrale del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo
  2. Compattare le cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle
  3. Riavviare Thunderbird
  4. Se il problema non è risolto, ricostruire l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
  5. Riavviare Thunderbird
  6. Se il problema non si è ancora risolto: click destro sulla cartella che contiene la mail illeggibile -> Proprietà -> [Ripara la cartella]

creator: barbaraF

content:
Thunderbird memorizza l'indice dei messaggi in file separati dall’archivio dei messaggi veri e propri Il dato 12346 messaggi - 317kb nasce probabilmente da questa situazione, l'indice contiene 12346 voci ma l'archivio reale è di pochi kb e contiene verosimilmente solo i messaggi più recenti.

I file con estensione .msf sono proprio quelli che contengono l'indice dei messaggi. Purtroppo da questi non è possibile ricavare i messaggi originali.

Se vuoi, riporta gli elenchi completi dei file che trovi nel profilo assieme alle relative dimensioni. Tuttavia se la cartella più grande è di 24 MB dubito che possa contenere un archivio corposo come quello di cui parlavi all'inizio che immagino contenesse migliaia di messaggi.

Potresti recuperare i messaggi dal server a seconda del protocollo che usi (IMAo o POP) e delle impostazioni che hai adottato.

Se in Tasto menu > Impostazioni > Generale avevi attivato la funzione Permetti a Ricerca di Windows di cercare nei messaggi potresti avere una serie di piccoli file con estensione .mozmsgs (un messaggio per ogni email). Da questi forse sarebbe possibile ricostruire l'archivio.

Altre soluzioni non me ne vengono in mente.

content: Solo una precisazione per la parte Permetti a Ricerca di Windows di cercare nei messaggi: - le cartelle hanno nel nome .mozmsgs - i singoli messaggi hanno estensione .wdseml

content:
something is missing, as users have responded 100% on these steps. Please review carefully and try again. Wording is a bit different from the help>troubleshooting steps, but the process is the same when profile is in default location.

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

You might also highlight archive folder on old pc, rightclick, select properties and verify that it is in the profile. Also, you can then look at the external media copy to verify.
creator: davidsk

content:
The simplest, non-technical way is to - install the addon, importexporttools NG - highlight a folder to remove, rightclick and select importexport option to export mbox - repeat for each folder. - you may now delete them

Later, when you want to see them, reverse the process: - highlight Local Folders - rightclick and select importexport option to import mbox and select a desired folder.

content:
Verified it was checked. Shut down/restarted Thunderbird. Same result.

Tried out Troubleshooting mode (as suggested in https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1478092), same result.

I do run a firewall and Adguard but verified nothing is being blocked.

The frustrating part is that gmail worked earlier this year and recently (not sure on the timeframe, but in the last 4-6 months) started giving me errors, saying it couldn't connect. I read through a bunch of forums and troubleshooting docs here at the time and decided to back up the mail file, delete the account, and re-add it. I couldn't get it to add (same error I've written about here) but I left it alone until I had a chance to spend some time trying to figure out what is going on.

Since I hadn't made any changes to Thunderbird when this all started, I assumed either an update to Thunderbird changed something or Google changed something. I'm not sure which yet.
creator: trentwhip-fox

content: Anything else I can try? Is there a setting for verbose logging? Is my only option to delete my existing installation and reinstall?
creator: trentwhip-fox

content:
Try it with Windows running in safe mode, to bypass any startup apps that might be interfering, especially security/AV/VPN apps.

Check the gmail website to confirm IMAP is enabled, and disable two-factor authentication if it's set on the account. Use the account password in the OAuth dialog, not an app password.

Remove any entries in Saved Passwords in Settings, then restart TB.
creator: sfhowes

content:
I finally found the solution. I use 2FA on my gmail account. I dug up a support page in the gmail docs that indicates 2FA is not compatible with current method and I must create an app password.

Once I did that and recreated my account (had to do it manually) - it now works.
creator: trentwhip-fox

content: I am having the same problem with adding a gmail-based email account to TB on Mac. Everything is up to date. The issue for me is that this specific account requires 2FA, so the workaround given here isn't possible. I can add the account to Apple Mail, and it launches the login sequence using Safari to allow it, and that works. So it seems like TB isn't able to launch a browser to allow the secondary (primary?) login? Feature request?

content: To see contacts in compose window, press F9 To see the send button, click view>toolbars and tick 'composition toolbar' when on compose window

creator: Condomgr

content: My concern is that many email hosts are rejecting mass mailings. If you post screenshot of the complete error message, that may help. If you do this regularly, and if your audience is fewer than a thousand or so, I encourage you to evaluate mailing services, such as Mailchimp, as they offer a free service if not too many messages are sent per month. And a plus is that they notify you of who actually reads the mail. :)
